verses.text: O God, by Your name, save me, and by Your might, vindicate me.
verses.comment: The use of 'name' signifies God's revealed character and authority. In the Old Testament, invoking God's name often implies seeking His presence and power—foreshadowing Christ's authority as revealed in the New Testament (cf. John 17:11-12). Catholic liturgy frequently invokes the Holy Name, reflecting this ancient tradition.

verses.text: O God, hear my prayer; give ear to the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: A plea for God to listen, echoing earlier Psalms. The structure reflects a pattern familiar in communal liturgical prayer, similar to the Psalms used in the Liturgy of the Hours—a practice foundational in the Catholic Church's devotional life.

verses.text: For strangers have risen against me, and violent men seek my life; they do not set God before them. Selah.
verses.comment: David faces enemies who act without reverence for God, recalling situations of persecution faced by the righteous—prefiguring Christ, who was persecuted by those who 'knew not the Father' (John 16:3). The 'Selah' invites reflective, meditative pause, as in traditional liturgical worship.

verses.text: Behold, God is my helper; the Lord is the Sustainer of my soul.
verses.comment: ‘Helper’ and ‘Sustainer’ highlight God's providential care, echoing typologically the Holy Spirit ('the Helper' in John 14:26). The Church Fathers saw God's ongoing sustenance as a model for how grace—the sacraments above all—continually nourishes and upholds the soul in the journey toward salvation.

verses.text: He will turn back the evil against my enemies; in Your faithfulness destroy them.
verses.comment: God’s justice is trusted to vindicate the righteous, a theme that points both to temporal deliverance and, ultimately, to final judgment at the end of time (cf. Matthew 25:31-46). Catholic theology sees God’s 'faithfulness' here as His covenant fidelity, fulfilled perfectly in Christ and perpetuated through His Church.

verses.text: With a freewill offering I will sacrifice to You; I will praise Your name, O LORD, for it is good.
verses.comment: 'Freewill offering' signals both gratitude and liturgical worship. Early Christians saw the Eucharist—the ultimate sacrifice of praise—as the fulfillment of Old Testament offerings, a central and unifying aspect of Catholic worship (cf. Hebrews 13:15).

verses.text: For He has delivered me from every trouble, and my eyes have gazed upon my enemies’ defeat.
verses.comment: David’s deliverance points ahead to Christ’s victory over sin and death. Spiritually, it also anticipates the triumph of the Church over all opposition, as promised by Christ (Matthew 16:18). The Psalm's ending inspires confidence in God's providence—expressed in trust, thanksgiving, and sacrificial worship.
